citations.narrative:
There is an outdoor enclosure that contains three red Kangaroos that had approximately 80ft of its perimeter fence
damaged after a storm. The 80ft of perimeter fence has not been replaced on the field side of the enclosure.
The perimeter fence acts as a secondary containment area or additional barrier to prevent other animals/people from
gaining access to the regulated animals.
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals,
such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and
elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter
fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the
Administrator.
To be corrected by: March 15, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is an outdoor enclosure that contains three red Kangaroos that had approximately 80ft of its perimeter fence 
damaged after a storm. The 80ft of perimeter fence has not been replaced on the field side of the enclosure. 
 
The perimeter fence acts as a secondary containment area or additional barrier to prevent other animals/people from 
gaining access to the regulated animals.  
 
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient 
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, 
such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and 
elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved  in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be 
constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going 
through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary 
enclosure to prevent  physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter 
fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved  in writing by the 
Administrator. 
 
To be corrected by: March 15, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
